content.question:
Instant ardentes Tyrii, pars ducere muros,

molirique arcem et manibus subvolvere saxa,

pars optare locum tecto et concludere sulco.

Iura magistratusque legunt sanctumque senatum;

5hic portus alii effodiunt; hic alta theatris

fundamenta locant alii, immanesque columnas

rupibus excidunt, scaenis decora alta futuris.

Aeneid 1. 423-429

Answer the following questions in English unless the question specifically asks you to write out Latin words. Number your answer to each question.

1. In lines 1-2 (Instant . . . saxa), which two Latin verbs are connected by the conjunction et (line 2) ?

2. In lines 1-3 (Instant . . . sulco), which two Latin words mean that these people work enthusiastically?

3. In lines 1-3 (Instant . . . sulco), (A) identify one Latin word that is an ablative of means and (B) translate it in context.

4. In this passage, which two Latin words can be translated “they make laws”?

5. What are the case and use of portus (line 5) ?

6. (A) Name one and only one literary device found in line 5 (hic . . . theatris) and (B) write out the Latin word or words that illustrate it.

7. Which Latin word in this passage is the subject of excidunt (line 7) ?

8. In lines 4-7 (Iura . . . futuris), which two different Latin words indicate the size of the Tyrians’ new city?

9. According to Venus earlier in Book 1, why are the Tyrians building a new city?

unit.text: 4: Teacher's Choice - Latin Poetry and Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 1 and 2

skill.text: 1.B: Describe how grammar contributes to the meaning and function of Latin words and phrases in context.
